description.narrative: Strengthening Climate Information And Early Warning Systems In Africa For Climate Resilient Development And Adaptation To Climate Change
independent political entity
Environment - policy, planning and administration
To strengthen the climate monitoring capabilities, early warning systems and available information for responding to climate shocks and planning adaptation to climate change in Benin.
1. Capacity as per capacity assessment scorecard. 2. Domestic finance committed to the relevant institutions to monitor extreme weather and climate change.

comment.narrative:
1. Limited capacity to generate EWS and CI on a national scale for extreme hydro-meteorological phenomena. Limited disaster risk-prevention capacity on national and local levels within ANPC. No Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) for alert communication by ANPC with the support of NGOs/CSOs.
Current score: 62 2. Existing budget plans do not have sufficient funds to maintain and operate the environmental monitoring infrastructure.
1. Capacity assessment target score of 157 for all combined EWS agencies. 2. 40% increase in domestic financing for equipment operation and maintenance across all institutions.

The EWS capacity for the mitigation of flooding risks has been created at the level of national institutions. Current Score = 90 Standard Operating Procedures for alert communication have been adopted by the Government. Planned domestic financing is done. An amount of 30,000 USD (around 10% increase) is funded bu domestic resources in 2014 and 246,200 USD is planned for 2015.

description.narrative: Enhanced capacity of national hydro-meteorological services (DNM/DG-Eau) and coastal monitoring institutions (CRHOB) to monitor extreme weather and climate change (droughts, floods, strong winds, coastal erosion, sea- level rise).
1. % national coverage for climate/weather monitoring. 2. Frequency and timeliness of climate-related data availability.

comment.narrative: 1. Currently, there is approximately 30% national coverage for climate/weather monitoring with respect to the optimal arrangements, as defined in the NHMS feasibility reports. 6 manual synoptic weather stations, 2 manual agro-climatological stations, 55 manual rainfall gauges, 2 manual flow meters (water level), 46 automatic flow meters (water level), 1 ADCP and 1 coastal monitoring station are in place. 2. Data from manual weather and hydrological stations is collected monthly and transmitted by post.

1. 60% national coverage to take steps in achieving NHMS optimal monitoring arrangements as defined in feasibility studies with 76 automatic flow meters (water level), 2 ADCPs, 3 automatic agro-meteorological/ climate stations, 2 automatic synoptic stations, 55 automatic rain gauges and rehabilitation of 6 manual synoptic stations and 20 manual agro-climatological stations. 2. Target for data transmission frequency: daily.

The following equipment is currently being procured and will be delivered in a few weeks: 3 automatic synoptic stations, 7 agro-climatic stations, 140 limnimetric staff-gauges, 20 automatic limnimetric recorders, 1 sea buoy, 2 multi-parameters and portable analysers of sea water, 2 ADCP (river and sea water) automatic flow and bathymetric measurement. The dispcrepacies between the procured equipments listed here and the target planned is due to some adaptation of the target specified in Project Document. During the time between Project Formulation end and Project beginning, the need of national institutions is progress and the news targets were adopted by national institutions in the framework of Project launching workshop. The water level for the main rivers is already being transmitted daily to the EWS server. The system is not yet operational for met data or oceano data.

description.narrative: Efficient and effective use of hydro-meteorological and coastal information for making early warnings and seasonal forecasts which feed into long-term development plans.

1. % of population with access to improved climate information and flood, drought, strong wind and coastal warnings (disaggregated by gender). 2. Development frameworks (The Poverty Reduction Strategy paper, PRSP (French: SCRP), the Programme d’Action Prioritaires (PAP), the Environmental Management Plan (PNDC-GEM) and the Agricultural Revival Strategy, NGSPR ) that integrate climate information in their formulation of poverty reduction strategies at the local levels. 3. Sector-specific strategies and plans that integrate climate risks (agriculture, health, and cotton production sectors).

comment.narrative: 1. There are 4 existing EWS initiatives for regional flood warnings and famine alerts, however, a national alert system concerned with extreme hydro-meteorological phenomena is lacking. There is also a limited understanding of the technical alert jargon (alerts are not translated into all national languages). There is also no mechanism for end-users (most vulnerable populations) to be involved in the alert process to ensure its sustainability. 2. Development frameworks do not incorporate any EWS/CI products such as risk maps or climate change predictions into long-term planning. 3. Sector-specific strategies do not include EWS/CI because the quality of weather forecasts and climate predictions is poor and not tailored for specific uses, particularly seasonal forecasts.

1. 50% increase in the population who has access to improved EWS/CI. 2. At least 2 of the PRSP policy briefs incorporate analyses of risk maps and/or climate change projections influencing long-term planning proposals. Target: integration into the revised SCRP (by 2015), PAP (by 2015) and NGSPR (by 2016). 3. Development of at least two tailored climate products and presentation of a market research plan on how to implement mobile phone based agricultural advisories, both supporting targeted weather/climate service delivery.

1. Percentage not yet assessed, but more people located in flooding areas (13 districts of Lower valley of Oueme River, 5 districts of Lower valley of Mono River and 2 boundary districts of Niger River) have quick access to warning messages on this risk (around 800,000 persons). Seasonal agro-hydro-climatic messages were disseminated in 14 local languages through 16 local meetings with farmers and producers (more than 500 farmers). 2. No progress at the current date 3. No progress at the current date

L’objectif général du PCM-BONOU est de promouvoir le Développement Durable à travers l’amélioration des conditions de vie des populations et leur bien- être dans un processus intégré, holistique et participatif.
